t: And having filled them with boldness through these words, and made them ready to die for the laws and the country, he divided his army into four parts.
And he appointed his brethren, Simon, and Joseph, and Jonathan, to lead every one his part, giving each of them fifteen hundred men.
And Esdrias read the holy book before them: and he gave them this for a watchword: The help of God. And himself leading the first band, he joined battle with Nicanor.
And the Almighty being their helper, they slew above nine thousand men: and having wounded and disabled the greater part of Nicanor's army, they forced them to fly.
And they took the money of them that came to buy them, and pursued them on every side. But being pressed by the time,
For it was the day before the sabbath, they forbore to pursue them any farther.
And when they had gathered together their arms, and their spoils, they kept the sabbath: blessing the Lord who had delivered them that day, distilling mercy upon them.
And after the sabbath, they divided the spoils to the feeble, and the widows, and the orphans: and the rest they took for themselves, and for their servants.
And when they had done these things, and made a common supplication, they besought the merciful Lord to be reconciled to his servants unto the end.

And they made an attack upon the troops of Timotheus, and Bacchides, and slew above twenty thousand of them, and they took possession of some strongholds: and they divided amongst themselves a very great booty, making equal distribution to the feeble, the orphans, the widows, and the aged.
And gathering together carefully all their arms, they laid them up in convenient places: and the rest of the spoils they carried to Jerusalem.
And they slew Philarches who was with Timotheus, a wicked man, who had caused many evils to the Jews.

And when they kept the feast of the victory at Jerusalem, they burnt Callisthenes, that had set fire to the holy gates, who had taken refuge in a certain house, rendering to him a worthy reward for his impiety.
Then that most wicked Nicanor, who had brought a thousand merchants to the sale of the Jews,

Being, through the Lord's help, brought down, thinking that he could now waylay that people, whom he despised more than any other, having put off his glorious apparel, fled away by the country like a fugitive, being exceedingly glad to have escaped.

So when he was come to Antioch, he boasted that he had overcome the Jews. And whereas he ought to have received a punishment for that which had been done by him, seeing that the Lord is the avenger of right, he went away with boasting.
Now when king Antiochus was returning from the countries of Persia,

He heard that there was in Persia a city called Persepolis, renowned for riches, and greatly abounding in money: and that Antiochus had attempted to take it, and to pillage it: but that they of the city had defended themselves, and he was put to flight.
And king Antiochus was exceedingly troubled in his mind: and being moved with indignation, he determined to make haste and to waste all the country of Judea.
Now when he was come as far as Ecbatana, he heard of the things that had happened to Nicanor and Timotheus.

And being exceedingly angry, he thought to revenge upon the Jews the injury done by them that had put him to flight. And therefore he commanded his chariot to be driven, without stopping, till he came into Judea. But the judgment of heaven pursued him, because he spoke so proudly, saying: That he would come to Jerusalem, and make it a common burying-place of the Jews.

But the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, struck him with an incurable and an invisible plague: for as soon as he had ended these words, a dreadful pain in his bowels came upon him, and violent torments of the inner parts.
And indeed very justly, seeing he had tormented the bowels of others with many and new torments.

But he in no wise ceased from his arrogance: but still swelling with pride, breathing out fire in his rage against the Jews, commanded that the journey should be hastened. And it came to pass as he was going on with violence, that he fell from the chariot, so that his limbs were much pained by a grievous bruising of the body.

Thus he that seemed to himself to command even the waves of the sea, being proud above the condition of man, and to weigh the high mountains in a balance, now being cast down to the ground, was carried in a litter, bearing witness to the manifest power of God.
So that worms swarmed out of the body of this wicked man, and whilst he lived in sorrow and pain, his flesh fell off, and the stench of his corruption was grievous to the whole army.
And thus through his intolerable stench, every one being unwilling to carry him, he died in great anguish in a strange country.
And Philip, one of his friends, carried away his body: and being afraid of the son of Antiochus, retired into Egypt to Ptolemee Philometor.
So king Antiochus died in this manner, being struck by God.
Now it happened that when king Antiochus was come into the higher countries, he heard that Elymais in Persia was a most noble city, and greatly abounding in silver and gold.

And that there was in it a temple very rich, wherein were weapons of gold, and breastplates, and shields, which Alexander, son of Philip, the Macedonian king, had left there, who reigned first in Greece.
So king Antiochus came, and attempted to take and pillage the temple: and he was not able to do it, because they of the city withstood him.
And he fled away from thence with disgrace, and returned to Babylon.
But one came, and told him what had happened concerning Judea and Jerusalem.
And he said: That he had sent Philip to Jerusalem, to take away all things that had been appointed:
And he had sent also Andronicus and Menelaus to kill all that he could find that were against him: and that after they were slain, he would set over the rest Lysias to be their governor.
Now these things that he spoke pleased not the king. And it happened that he fell sick, and perceived that he should die.
Wherefore he called for all his friends, and said to them: Sleep is gone from my eyes, and I am fallen away in my heart.
And I said in my heart: Into what tribulation am I come! and from what a flood of sorrow am I now compassed! I that was of late cheerful and beloved in my command.

Now I remember the evils that I have done in Jerusalem, from whence also I took away all the vessels of gold and silver that were in the temple, and I sent to destroy the inhabitants of Judea without any cause.
Therefore do I know that for this cause these evils have found me: and behold I perish with great grief in a strange land.
Then he called Philip, one of his friends, and made him regent over all his kingdom.
And he gave him the crown, and his robe, and his ring, that he should go to Antiochus his son, and should bring him up to be king.
So king Antiochus died there in the year one hundred and forty-nine.
Then Lysias understood that Antiochus was dead, and he made Antiochus his son king, whom he brought up from his childhood, and he called his name Eupator.
And when they that were in the castle had shut up the Israelites round about the sanctuary, they sought always their hurt, and to strengthen the Gentiles.
Then Judas purposed to destroy them: and he called together all the people, and besieged them.
And there came to them all the wicked men of Israel, and they took the part of them that were besieged.
And he went about, and besieged Bethsura, a strong city: and they withstood him, and hindered him from proceeding.
Then Judas departed from Jerusalem to Bethsura, and Lysias came with him with a great army.
And when Judas and his company had knowledge that Lysias was coming, they sent messengers to the Lord, that he would send his holy angel to save Israel.
Then Lysias rose up, and took with him about eighty thousand footmen, and all his horsemen, and he came against Judas.
And when he was come to Bethsura, Judas met him with a few men.

But when they saw the army of the enemy coming, they prayed to the Lord, and said: Blessed art thou, O Saviour of Israel, who didst break the violence of the mighty by the hand of thy servant David, and didst deliver up the camp of the aliens into the hands of Jonathan the son of Saul, and of his armourbearer.
Shut up this army in the hands of thy people Israel, and let them be confounded in their host and their horsemen.
Strike them with fear, and let the boldness of their strength be dismayed: and let them feel thy power.
Cast them down, and destroy them in the sight of them that love thee: and let all that know thy name, praise thee with hymns.
And they joined battle: and there fell of the army of Lysias about five thousand men.
And when Lysias saw that his army was put to flight, and how bravely Judas had fought, and they that were with him, he retired to Antioch, and purposed to return again with a greater army.
Then Judas and his brethren said: Behold our enemies are discomfited: let us go up now to cleanse the holy places, and to dedicate them.
And all the army assembled together, and they went up into mount Sion.

And they saw the sanctuary desolate, and the altar profaned, and the gates burnt, and shrubs growing up in the courts as in a forest, or on the mountains, and the chambers that were in it pulled down.
And they rent their garments, and made great lamentation, and they cast ashes upon their heads:
And they fell down to the ground on their faces, and they sounded with the trumpets of alarm, and they cried toward heaven.
Then Judas appointed men to fight against them that were in the castle, till they had cleansed the holy places.
And he chose priests without blemish, whose will was towards the law:
And they cleansed the holy places, and took away the stones that had been defiled into an unclean place.
And they considered about the altar of holocausts that had been defiled, what they should do with it.
And it came into their mind that they should pull it down, lest it should be a perpetual reproach to them, because the Gentiles had defiled it: so they took it down.
And they laid up the stones in the mountain of the temple in a convenient place, till there should come a prophet, and give answer concerning them.
Then they took whole stones according to the law, and built a new altar according to the former:
And they built up the holy places, and the things that were within the temple: and they sanctified the temple, and the courts.
And they made new holy vessels: and they brought in the candlestick, and the altar of incense, and the table into the temple.
And they put incense upon the altar, and lighted up the lamps that were upon the candlestick: and these things gave light in the temple.
And they set the loaves upon the table, and hung up the veils, and finished all the works that they made.
Now on the five and twentieth day of the month Casleu, which is called December, in the year one hundred and forty-eight, they arose before the morning.
And they offered sacrifice according to the law upon the new altar of holocausts which they had made.
According to the ordinance and rite, they offered holocausts, and burnt incense, and set forth the loaves.

And when they had done these things, they besought the Lord that he would not suffer them to fall any more into such evils: but if they should at any time sin against him, that he himself would chastise them with mercy, and not deliver them up to nations that were barbarous and blasphemous.
Now it came to pass, that on the same day that the temple had been defiled by the Gentiles, on the very same day it was cleansed again, to wit, on the five and twentieth day of the month Casleu.

And others, likewise, ascended against them that were besieged, taking them in the rear, and set fire to the towers, and kindling pyres, they burned the blasphemers alive. Howbeit, breaking down the gates, the first received the rest of the host, and having taken possession of the city, they were at their head.
And they slew Timothy, who had hid himself in a cistern, and with him Chereas his brother, and Apollophanes.
And after they had accomplished these deeds, they blessed with hymns and praises the Lord, who granted such great benefits unto Israel, and gave them the victory.
A very little while after this, Lysias, guardian and kinsman of the king, who was over the affairs of the realm, being sore troubled at the things that had befallen,
gathered together about fourscore thousand footmen, with all his horsemen, and came against the Jews, purposing to make the City an habitation for the Greeks,
and to lay the sanctuary under tribute, as were the other places of worship of the nations, and to sell the high priesthood every year,
taking no account of the power of God, but being fully confident in his myriads of foot soldiers, and his thousands of horsemen, and his fourscore elephants.
And having entered into Judea, he drew near unto Bethzur, which is a strong place distant from Jerusalem about five furlongs, and he pressed it sore.

Now when Maccabeus and they that were with him heard that Lysias was besieging the fortresses, they besought the Lord with groanings and tears, together with the multitude, that He would send a good angel unto Israel, to save them.

Then Maccabeus himself, first taking up arms, exhorted the others to expose themselves with him to the peril, to succour their brethren. And they, therefore, rushed forth together, being filled with zeal;
and they were yet nigh unto Jerusalem, when a horseman clothed in white appeared at their head, waving weapons of gold.
Then all at once blessed the merciful God, and felt themselves animated with such zeal, that they were ready to pierce, not only men, but even the most savage beasts, and walls of iron.
And they advanced in battle array, aided by an ally come from heaven, the Lord having had mercy on them.
They therefore rushed upon the enemies like lions, and laid low upon the ground eleven thousand footmen, and sixteen hundred horsemen, and compelled all the rest to flee.
Most of them escaped only wounded and without arms. Lysias himself saved his life by a shameful flight.

But Lysias, who lacked not understanding, considered within himself the defeat he had sustained; understanding that the Hebrews were invincible, since the mighty God fought with them, he sent unto them an embassy,
to bring them to an agreement upon all equitable terms, and promised to constrain the king to become their friend.
And Maccabeus consented to all that Lysias proposed, having regard only to the public weal. All that Maccabeus transmitted in writing unto Lysias concerning the Jews, the king granted.
The letter written unto the Jews by Lysias was worded thus: "Lysias unto the people of the Jews, greetings.
John and Absalom, your envoys, having delivered unto me the instrument transcribed below, have entreated me to ratify the things which it contained.
